text:
Malcolm Turnbull Malcolm Turnbull refuses to confirm whether he donated $2m to Liberals 
Despite making comments supporting real time disclosure of donations, instead of current six-month delay, PM won’t detail his personal funding Malcolm Turnbull says he would have no objection to more timely political donation reforms and said it was a matter for the joint standing committee on electoral matters. Photograph: Mick Tsikas/AAP View more sharing options Wednesday 1 February 2017 05.36 GMT Last modified on Wednesday 1 February 2017 05.38 GMT 
Malcolm Turnbull has refused to confirm whether he donated a reported $2m to the Liberal party, just moments after saying that public information should be released “as close to real time as possible”. 
On Wednesday, donations information from 2015-16 over the period leading up to the July election was released by the Australian Electoral Commission. 
The disclosures did not show any donation from Turnbull to the Liberal party, despite reports he had donated close to $2m, suggesting the donation was made after 1 July. 2016 election donation disclosures: no money from Malcolm Turnbull listed Read more 
At his first major speech for 2017 at the National Press Club, Turnbull was asked about whether he would support reforms to allow people to see donations in a more timely manner. 
Turnbull suggested the current disclosure rules were a result of historical administration requirements. He said he would have no objection to more timely donation reforms and said it was a matter for the joint standing committee on electoral matters (Jscem), which is examining political donations . 
“Obviously in the 21st century, just as with parliamentarians’ expenses, the closer, the more timely any matter of public importance, any public information, that can be disclosed more promptly – or in as close to real time as possible – should be. 
“I’ve got no doubt that’s one of the matters they will be looking at.” 
However, when asked whether he would disclose his own donations to the Liberal party ahead of the February 2018 disclosure, Turnbull declined. 
“My donations to the Liberal party have been regular and generous and I would encourage others to do the same,” he said. 
A Guardian analysis has found that, of the total income received by the Liberal, National, Labor and Greens parties, the origin of a substantial proportion is unknown. For the Liberal party, it is more than half of their total receipts. 
Parties are only required to declare details of donations or payments over $13,000, so for payments under the threshold the name of the donor or source of the payment is unknown. Parties are, however, required to declare the total amount they receive in the financial year, which is the total of all payments regardless of the amount. 
For the Liberal party, 57.2% of their total income had no source, followed by 41.5% for the Greens, 40.1% for Labor and 33.5% for the National party. 
Averaged out across those four major parties, this means voters have no idea of the source of close to half (47.7%) of their income. chart 
While Jscem is expected to report back to parliament in March, Labor has committed to a range of reforms. 
Labor’s policy would reduce the donation disclosure limit from $13,200 (indexed) to a fixed $1,000, ban foreign donations, ban donation splitting (to keep under the limit), ban anonymous donations above $50, link public funding to campaign expenditure and introduce new offences and tougher penalties for abuses the system. Political donations 2015-16: search the declarations by Australian parties Read more 
The Greens senator Lee Rhiannon urged real time disclosure of donations and payments as well as a lower disclosure limit. She said the most recent disclosures show the total amount of declared donations and payments made to Australian political parties since 1998 had topped $1bn. 
“More transparency is absolutely needed but it does not stop the cosy relationship between vested interests and political parties,” she said. “Only bans and strict caps on donations and election expenditure will achieve that. 
“Transparency alone will not stop the Parakeelia spin cycle, it won’t stop resource companies sending millions to the major parties and it won’t cork the flow of money for influence from other vested interests.” Topics
